Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the fact that President Obama has "not proposed one thing" to change the tax rate disparity between Warren Buffett and his secretary. This is because President Obama has shown interest in tax legislation and has even proposed the "Buffett rule" in the past.
Understate: The claim may be understating the efforts made by President Obama to address tax inequality. It fails to mention that President Obama has identified tax reform as an area where he could find agreement with Republican leaders and has made proposals in his State of the Union address.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up the assertion that President Obama has not proposed any measures to address tax inequality. It does not provide specific evidence or examples to support this claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that President Obama has not taken any action to address the tax rate disparity between Warren Buffett and his secretary. This assumption ignores the existence of the "Buffett rule" proposal and other efforts made by President Obama.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider the alternative explanation that President Obama has made proposals and efforts to address tax inequality, but they may not have been successful in implementing the desired changes.
